children.subject: YAY
same asking
Working on it.  Probably by end of week.
WOOOHOOOOOOO
Permission codes are available now, you should have gotten an email describing how to get them.  If not, email me.

actually, here is the email.

---------------------------------------------------------

Hello All,
Please read this carefully, before grabbing a permission code.
They are available in a google drive spreadsheet.  If you take one, please mark the column labeled Taken, with some indication that you took it.  Feel free to put your name in the Name column, but no need, it is public to all Berkeley calnet users.
There are 150, which should be enough, and I can get more, and I will if they run out.   I anticipate that everyone gets in, and in fact, that the enrollment will drop to fit in the room soon enough.
I am holding my breath, hoping this works out smoothly, and you HAVE TO cooperate here and mark that you have taken a permission code or bad things will happen.
In any case, the link for the drive folder is here.
Fingers crossed that this goes smoothly....
Best,
Satish Rao
Is there any update on if/when/how we would receive these permission codes? Thanks!

I am getting a bunch of people whose emails I see that I sent to who have not gotten them. 

Can anyone who actually recieved the bulk email let me know, so I can resend as necessary?  Just let me know below.

Thanks.

Satish Rao
Yes. Screencasted.
Any chance that the class will be webcasted?
No inclass final during finals week.
I'm sorry but that is a little ambiguous - is there a final or not?

It seems like the instructors answers on this thread indicate that either there will be a take home final or final projects/presentations. Either way, there should be no conflict with any other classes finals.
Can an instructor confirm whether or not there is a final exam (so I make sure not to conflict with any other class)?
We are working on a syllabus that will work with this class size.  Projects/presentations may not be done this semester.
Will the final project/presentation be finished before finals week (or is that the plan)?
Obviously this might not still be the case but it used to say 2040 VLSB
2040 VLSB, as far as I know.
Is there an update on which room the class is located? Eecs.berkeley.edu, berkeley.collegescheduler.com, and berkeleytime say the location is "Valley LSB" without specifying a room number.
so when I took it (sp17), there was no discussion even though it was formally "scheduled" on the catalog. and I don't think the class has ever run discussion section. ymmv obviously
So how can I enroll the class with a schedule conflict? Even there is no discussion..

Thank you Keyhan! I'm the anon below, and your answer addresses my question, too.

As for the schedule conflict problem, I saw a similar followup in @7915 and that post seems to takes care of enrollment problems. But it looks like the conflict enrollment problem is not resolved for them either :(
sorry, i don't really know about the logistics. try emailing cs advising and see what they say?
We don't normally have discussion, I am looking into why it is on the schedule.

It is on the schedule, but we will not be holding it.  It is just a 3 unit class, the discussion section is a remnant of something on the books from years past (some Berkeley beauracrocy thing, that I need to fix.)
Is it possible to move the discussion time to a different time? Another class does not allow any time conflict :(
Let me check.
Hey if this is still an issue, send me an email.
I am having a schedule conflict with the discussion on Friday 9-10AM, is it the only discussion and it is mandatory?

Different anon here. I have a schedule conflict with the discussion, too (I have a language class during that time). I talked to my language class instructor and he allowed me to be absent every Friday, but it would be great if the discussion is also screencasted and attendance is not required if we watch the screencast. Could Professor Rao confirm whether discussion is also screencasted? 

And, I'm not sure if this is the right place to ask about this, (if not, please direct me to the right place), but I have problems with schedule conflict enrollment: schedule planner says CS270 allows conflicts and the other class does not. However, the system was blocking me from enrolling in CS270 because of the conflict, so I dropped my language class and enrolled in CS270. But I still want my language class. Any clues on how this can be resolved?

It's pretty early to be asking this question and I doubt anyone has the answer to it. There have been previous semesters where Rao has both offered and not offered 270 for whatever reasons, so there's really no way of knowing.
270 historically has only been offered in the Spring - and not always each year at that. join while you still can!
Will 270 also be taught next fall?
Yes.  See the link above, there are new permission codes.
Thanks!
Are there any more permission codes/can more be requested? All the ones on the spreadsheet have been used and I haven't been able to enroll. Thank you.
Thank you Prof Rao!!! Really appreciate your support for our love of algorithms :) :)

history.content:
Hello,

I have been getting many emails from undergraduates about whether/how to get in the queue for this course.

Here is the link for permission codes.   Please indicate when you have taken one.

There is a previous website. 

I make no guarantees on content, though.  Quoting from @7884.

"While I do take mostly undergraduate students, I run it as a graduate course, which means I teach whatever I feel like and the material is more conceptually difficult than undergraduate.  Also the support that undergraduates (e.g., weekly homeworks, a great text, all day office hours, etc) are used to is not provided. So it is really on you to learn the material, so you should be interested enough to do so."

There will be some professor, and some TA office hours, just not the almost 40 hours people are used to.

Best.

Satish Rao
history.subject: CS270 Poll for Undergraduates from Rao.

Hello,

I have been getting many emails from undergraduates about whether/how to get in the queue for this course.

Here is the link for permission codes.   Please indicate when you have taken one.

There is a previous website. 

I make no guarantees on content, though.  Quoting from @7884.

"While I do take mostly undergraduate students, I run it as a graduate course, which means I teach whatever I feel like and the material is more conceptually difficult than undergraduate.  Also the support that undergraduates (e.g., weekly homeworks, a great text, all day office hours, etc) are used to is not provided. So it is really on you to learn the material, so you should be interested enough to do so."

There will be some professor, and some TA office hours, just not the almost 40 hours people are used to.

Also, I won't distribute enrollment codes to undergraduates  prior to January as graduate course enrollment is typically done at that time by graduate students who are the first audience that this course is available to.

Best.

Satish Rao

history.subject: CS270 Poll for Undergraduates from Rao.

history.content:
Hello,

I have been getting many emails from undergraduates about whether/how to get in the queue for this course.

I will not give out permission codes until after phase 2.  Please fill out this if you are interested.  I try to accomodate everyone and will ask for a larger room if there is interest.

There is a previous website. 

I make no guarantees on content, though.  Quoting from @7884.

"While I do take mostly undergraduate students, I run it as a graduate course, which means I teach whatever I feel like and the material is more conceptually difficult than undergraduate.  Also the support that undergraduates (e.g., weekly homeworks, a great text, all day office hours, etc) are used to is not provided. So it is really on you to learn the material, so you should be interested enough to do so."

There will be some professor, and some TA office hours, just not the almost 40 hours people are used to.

Also, I won't distribute enrollment codes to undergraduates  prior to January as graduate course enrollment is typically done at that time by graduate students who are the first audience that this course is available to.

Best.

Satish Rao
